relation: Course introduction and timeline; Bird identification (Optics, Guides and Notes. Homework: Sibley Field Guide pags. 10-17)
Topography and Field Marks (Homework: Sibley Field Guide pags. 18-24); Feet, Beaks and Body Form; Field exercises, start project thinking
Field research techniques, hypotheses testing, study design, and data analysis
Anderson et al. 1979 Survey of local birds (Pink Ravine), Project guidelines discussion and selection (written ideas)
Banding demo, Pomfret Center, Connecticut Audubon Society
Ortega & Capen 1999, Local birding (Mansfield Hollow), Field notebooks (First Submission)
Review; Individual project presentations; Paper submission (Introduction and Methods)
Individual project data collection I (Methods adjustment)
Memorial day: Individual project data collection III (Final)
Survey of coastal birds / Field notebooks (Final Submission)
Project presentations and assisted work on the paper
Review session in preparation for the final; PAPER SUBMISSION (FINAL)

textBeforeTable: Tentative* schedule o Sunscreen o Insect repellent (ticks, mosquitoes) o Birding by Ear: Eastern and Central North America o Sibley’s birding basics • Recommended o Closed-toe shoes (no sandals) or hiking boots, & proper outdoor clothing (poison ivy, weather) o Field notepad/notebook ( Basic guidelines) o Binoculars (available from us if you don’t have any) o The Sibley Field Guide to the Birds of Eastern North America • Required Course Materials ➢ Improve collaboration skills ➢ Develop a research project ➢ Learn and apply basic field techniques, study design, and data analysis ➢ Learn how to take field notes ➢ Acquire bird identification skills Course Objectives Office hours: variable & flexible (call, email, drop by) Phone: 860-486-0309 Office: Biol/Pharm 404 Instructor: Alejandro Rico Meets: 8 am to 11 am, TLS 371 Intensive Summer Session, May 13th - 31st, 2013 MTWThF EEB 3898: Field Methods in Ornithology Revision as of 13:21, 16 May 2013
textAfterTable: *: Schedule is subject to change pending weather conditions, or unforeseen birding and research opportunities. Grading Exams: May 22nd (MIDTERM) [50 points]; May 31st (FINAL) [50 points] Project Paper: May 21st (Intro and Methods) [30 points]; May 30th (Final) [50 points] Project Presentations: May 21st (Intro and Methods) [20 points]; May 29th (Final) [25 points] Field Notebook Submissions: May 20th (First) [20 points]; May 28th (Final) [25 points] Field trips = Birding exercises (5 points each): Dates will be weather dependent [30 points] Total: [300 points] Grading scale: A = 100-90%, B = 89-80%, C = 79-70%, D = 69-60%, F = 59-0%.
